Department of Organic Chemistry Faculty of Chemistry University of Science Ho Chi Minh City Viet Nam Recently, the catalytic conversion of fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) has attracted much interest. The idea of a low-cost, sustainable, energy-efficient method is critical to obtain excellent yield and selectivity for the target product 5-HMF. In this work, microwave (MW) irradiation was chosen as a heating source for the conversion of fructose to 5-HMF with the presence of various amorphous carbons containing Brønsted acid sites as catalysts in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as a solvent. The catalysts’ morphology, surface functional groups, thermal stability, and compositions of the obtained solids were examined by scanning electron microscope (SEM), elemental mapping, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), energy dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (EDX), Raman spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques. The effect of solvent, heating technique, MW power, time, and catalytic loading on the reaction was studied thoroughly. The highest 5-HMF yield of 79.9% and 5-HMF selectivity of 79.7% were achieved with the optimal condition. 5-HMF was easily separated using a liquid-liquid extraction procedure with high purity. Moreover, the catalyst can be quickly recovered and reused. MW irradiation has proved to selectively and efficiently promote the formation of 5-HMF with high yield in a short reaction time. A mechanism for the formation 5-HMF from fructose was also proposed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fructose Dehydration 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Amorphous carbon Microwave irradiation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Most chemistry activities were carried out at high temperatures using traditional heating devices like an oil bath for hours. Microwave irradiation, on the other hand, has long been acknowledged to be a state-of-the-art technology that can boost chemical reaction efficiency [1]. Microwave radiation converts electromagnetic energy directly into heat energy via dipole rotation and ionic conduction at high frequencies (300 MHz to 300 GHz) [2,3]. As a result, the reaction media and the biomass materials are rapidly and selectively heated. Since Gedye and coworkers reported the term “microwave-assisted” synthesis for the first time in 1986 [4], a wide range of work on biomass conversion has been conducted with the assistance of microwave irradiation, including chemical synthesis, digestion, extraction, drying, cooking, and pyrolysis [5–9]. Microwave-assisted heating provides various advantages over conventional heating for many reasons. Firstly, MW irradiation allows fast, direct, and efficient heating of the target molecules due to their uniform and volumetric arrangement, resulting in time- and energy-saving processes [10]. Secondly, MW irradiation is easily controllable, leading to higher yields and shorter reaction times [11]. Finally, microwave-assisted reactions are selective, which leads to a decrease in side products [12]. MW irradiation also reduces the reaction activation energy [13]. A study examining the energy efficiency of a conventional oil-bath organic synthesis with a microwave-assisted one found that most chemical reactions employing microwave irradiation as a source of energy on a laboratory scale may assume considerable energy savings (up to 85-fold) [14]. Cottier and co-workers developed a microwave technique that yielded 28% 5-HMF in aqueous fructose combined with inorganic phosphates for 3 min [15]. A high 5-HMF yield of 82% from the microwave-assisted conversion of fructose with the catalysis of a mixture between betaine and formic acid in a water/MIBK biphasic system at 160 °C for 60 minutes of reaction time was reported by Delbecq et al. [16] Lyu and co-workers also reported a study using surface functionalized carbon under microwave irradiation condition to achieve 89.2% of 5-HMF from fructose at 70 °C after 5 min [17]. Among the 12 principles of green chemistry, the need for “energy efficiency” can be considered one of the most important principles [18], so MW irradiation has tended to be a safe and effective heating method for reaction processes. Humanity's continuous use of carbon sources caused a decrease in fossil energy stocks and climate change due to CO2 emissions [19,20]. As a consequence of this action, the economy has shifted to displace fossil-based supplies with renewable and environmentally friendly ones [21]. In this regard, 5-HMF has attracted considerable interest as a substrate to synthesize various compounds and liquid transportation fuels [22–24]. Carbohydrates account for 75% of all biomass resources and cellulose on the planet [25]. Recently, there have been several studies to convert biomass into 5-HMF with different catalysts [17,26–35]. Because the conversion of carbohydrates to 5-HMF invariably involves these sugars in the final reaction sequence, the dehydration of fructose serves as a typical reaction for the preparation of 5-HMF from biomass-derived carbohydrates [36]. The dehydration of fructose into 5-HMF has been studied extensively, where a variety of different kinds of acid catalysts such as H2SO4, HCl, and H3PO4 have been utilized [21,37–39], organic acids (oxalic acid and levulinic acid) [40], H-form zeolites [41], transition metal ions [42–45], solid metal phosphates [46–48], and acidic cation exchange resins [37,39,49,50]. Homogeneous acids as catalysts are efficient and can reach moderate 5-HMF yields (40–60%) with good fructose transformation (70–90%) [40], but they have significant limitations, including separating and recycling, along with corrosion in acidic medium. As a result, it is critical to design more ecologically friendly and efficient solid acid catalysts to displace liquid acid catalysts [17,51]. Earlier research has shown that ion exchange resins (such as Amberlyst15 and DOWEX) may be used as a green solid acid catalyst for producing 5-HMF [52–54]. However, these catalysts can be performed in low reaction temperatures below 130 °C due to their thermal stability, making it challenging to improve 5-HMF selectivity [52–54]. Other solid acids, including H-form zeolites and metal phosphates, could be recycled and provided good selectivity (60–90%) but only poor fructose conversion (30- 60%) even after 2 h of reaction time [47,55]. Biomass-derived carbonaceous materials prepared by pyrolytic treatment of sugar can be used as acidic solid catalysts for many reactions [56–58] at high temperatures. Amorphous carbon has been employed as a green and solid acidic catalyst in numerous organic processes because it is easy to use, easy to control, straightforward to store, and has a high recycling and reusable ability. Qi and co-workers reported a cellulose-derived carbonaceous sulfonated solid catalyst as a catalyst for the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF in the ionic liquid 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([BMIM][Cl]). At 80 °C and after a 10 min reaction time, a remarkably high 5-HMF yield of 80% was achieved [59]. Among the solvents used for the conversion of biomass to 5-HMF, water turns out to be an environmentally friendly solvent, and recently, there have been some studies applying water as a solvent for this process [29–32]. However, in water, 5-HMF rehydrates to form levulinic acid and formic acid, so this solvent is ineffective. The other helpful solvent for this process is an ionic liquid. 1-Alkyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride was employed as a solvent, and CrCl2 as a catalyst for forming 5-HMF from fructose by Zhao et al. [42]. At the reaction temperature of 120 °C and after 3 h, a maximum 5-HMF yield of 73% was obtained. Even though ionic liquids are sophisticated due to their controllability of characteristics, the expensive cost of these solvents prevents them from being used on a large scale. Because of its high sugar solubility, capacity to control side reactions, stability of the furanose form of fructose, and increase of fructose dehydration to 5-HMF, DMSO was widely utilized in biomass conversion to 5-HMF [60]. In conclusion, developing an energy-efficient and straightforward procedure for the conversion of fructose to 5-HMF is still an important task. There have been some earlier studies focusing on hydrothermal techniques to synthesize solid acid catalysts [17,33], but these processes contained many raw ingredients, lots of steps, and the obtained materials have few acidities. In this study, microwave irradiation from an easily accessible commercial microwave oven was used as a heating source for the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF in DMSO solvent. In this study, various amorphous carbons bearing Brønsted acid sites were synthesized via the one-step hydrothermal carbonization of D-glucose with different organic and inorganic acids in water to use as green catalysts with high acidities. Moreover, various reaction parameters, such as heating method, catalyst loading, substrate nature, solvent nature, scale-up ability, and catalyst recovery ability, were examined to optimize the reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Unless otherwise specified, all commercially available reagent-grade compounds were acquired from chemical suppliers and utilized as supplied without additional processing. D-glucose monohydrate (99%) was purchased from Xilong. Fructose (>99.5%) was purchased from Merck. Oxalic acid dihydrate (>99%) was purchased in Fisher. Dimethyl sulfoxide (99.5%) was supplied by Guangdong Guanghua Sci-Tech Co. Ethyl acetate (>99%) and n-hexane (>99%) were supplied by Chemsol (Viet Nam). All studies utilized deionized (DI) water from the Millipore system (MilliQ®). (Merck), thin-layer chromatography (60F-254, TLC) was purchased from Merck. 2.2 Preparation of the catalysts Solid acid catalysts were synthesized by one-step hydrothermal carbonization according to the procedure developed by Xiao et al. [61] with a little modification ( Scheme 1 ). For a typical procedure, a solution of glucose (7.5 g), citric acid.H2O (2.5 g), oxalic acid dihydrate (0.031 mol), and distilled water (50 to 60 mL) was charged in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated in an oven at 200 °C for 6 h. Black-brown carbonaceous material was obtained by filtration and washed thoroughly with water, followed by ethanol. The solid acid catalyst CC-oxa was dried at 80 °C for 5 h in an oven. The other nine samples were obtained from the same procedure but replaced oxalic acid dihydrate with p-toluenesulfonic acid (pTSA), lactic acid, benzoic acid, H2SO4 98%, HCl 36%, HNO3 63%, trichloroacetic acid, adipic acid, or oleic acid to form CC-pTSA, CC-lac, CC-ben, CC-H2SO4, CC-HCl, CC-HNO3, CC-TCA, CC-adi, or CC-ole, respectively. These ten catalysts can be collectively denoted as CC-acids. A TGA Instruments Q-500 recorded TGA with an airflow of 99.99% purity. FT-IR analysis was performed using a Bruker VERTEX 70 Series spectrometer with KBr pellets. XRD was carried out at 40 kV and 40 mA utilizing a Cu Kα radiation source in the 2θ range from 5° to 80° with a scanning step duration of 4° min−1. The Raman measurement was conducted by Horiba Xplora Plus Raman with a 532 nm laser focusing on a spot of about 300 µm in diameter on the surfaces. Elemental compositions of the synthesized materials were characterized by EDX mapping and SEM using JSM-IT200 InTouchScope™ SEM Series with an acceleration voltage of 10 kV. Acid-base titrations were performed using a Professional benchtop pH meter from Trans Instruments model BP3001. For the measurement of total functional groups (-SO3H, -COOH, and -OH groups) on the CC-acids' surface, the titrations were performed according to Wang et al. [62] with a slight modification. The detailed steps were as follows: The catalyst (80 mg) was treated with a mixture of 0.05 mol L−1 aqueous solution of NaOH (40 mL) and DI water (40 mL). At room temperature, the mixture was agitated for 60 min using ultrasonic irradiation and then magnetically stirred for 20 h. After filtration, the filtrate was titrated with 5 mL of a HCl (0.05 mol L−1) solution. The titration of every CC-acid was repeated twice. The total content of functional groups is calculated as the formula (mmol g−1): ( V N a O H * C N a O H − V H C l * C H C l ) * V t o t a l f i l t r a t e m * V f i l t r a t e The catalytic activities of the CC-acid catalysts were elucidated by turnover number (TON), turnover frequency (TOF), E-factor, process mass intensity (PMI), and space-time yield (STY). The formulas to calculate these numbers are presented as follows: TON = moles of 5 − HMF moles active acid sites TOF ( h − 1 ) = TON time E − factor = mass of waste mass of 5 − HMF PMI = mass of fructose input mass of 5 − HMF output STY ( kgm − 3 h − 1 ) = mass of 5 − HMF the volume of reactor used x reaction time 2.3 Experimental conditions A typical reaction was conducted in a 20 mL vial with a screw cap containing a 3 mL solution of a reactant and a catalyst in a solvent in a commercial microwave oven purchased from Sharp Corporation, Japan (model R-203VN-M, maximum power 800 W, volume 20 L, size 430 × 33 × 250 mm) at the lowest power level 80 W for the desired time. A typical reaction was conducted in a 20 mL vial with a screw cap, containing a 3 mL solution of fructose (1 mmol), CC-oxa (5 mg) as a catalyst in DMSO (3 mL) as a solvent in a microwave oven at the lowest power level 80 W for the desired time. After completion of the reaction, approximately 0.1 g of the product mixture was taken out, diluted to 5 mL by DI water, then filtered with a 0.45 µm membrane nylon filter before being analyzed with HPLC-DAD to calculate the yields of the products (5-HMF, DFF, LA, Fur, and FDCA). Fructose was detected by a PRP-X 100 Anion Exchange HPLC column (10 µm, 4.1 × 250 mm) and an AB SCIEX Triple Quad 5500 LC/MS/MS System with electrospray ionization in negative ion mode with the temperature maintained at 25 °C, and the mixture of acetonitrile and water flowing at 1.2 mL min−1 as the mobile phase. The formulas to calculate fructose conversion and 5-HMF selectivity are: Fructose conversion ( % ) = 1 − mass of fructose in the mixture mass of initial fructose x 100 5 − HMF selectivity ( % ) = 5 − HMF yield fructose conversion x 100 5-HMF, furfural (Fur), formic acid (FA), levulinic acid (LA), 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), and 2,5-furandicarboxylic (FDCA) were detected by a C18 (4.6 × 250 mm) column with H2SO4/H2O 2.5 mM flowing at 0.7 mL min−1 as the mobile phase. The formulas to calculate 5-HMF, Fur, FA, LA, DFF, and FDCA yields were presented as follows: 5 − HMF yield ( % ) = moles of 5 − HMF moles of initial fructose x 100 DFF yield ( % ) = moles of DFF moles of initial fructose x 100 LA yield ( % ) = moles of LA moles of initial fructose x 100 FDCA yield ( % ) = moles of FDCA moles of initial fructose x 100 Fur yield ( % ) = moles of Fur moles of initial fructose x 100 2.4 The isolation of 5-HMF after the reaction and product characterization After the reaction, the mixture was added to 25 mL of DI water. Then, the liquid was extracted with 20 mL of ethyl acetate, and the ethyl acetate layer was taken out. Next, the aqueous layer was continuously extracted with 3 × 10 mL ethyl acetate, and the ethyl acetate layers were combined. After drying with anhydrous Na2SO4, the combined ethyl acetate layer was evaporated at reduced pressure. The solid product was column chromatographed, and elution solvent n-hexane/ethyl acetate=3/2. The product was characterized by 1H NMR and 13C NMR in CDCl3 on a Bruker Avance-500 MHz NMR spectrometer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization Ten solid acid catalysts were synthesized according to the procedure reported by Xiao and coworkers [61] by 6 h one-step hydrothermal carbonization of a mixture of D-glucose.H2O (7.5 g), citric acid.H2O (2.5 g), acid (0.031 mmol), and DI water (50 to 60 mL) in an autoclave at 200 °C. The as-synthesized catalysts were washed with DI water, then ethanol, and dried in an oven at 80 °C for 5 h. Ten catalysts were elucidated by FT-IR, EDX, TGA, XRD, SEM, Raman spectroscopy, and acid-base titration. The results of CC-oxa were represented in Fig. 1 . The FT-IR spectrum of CC-oxa (Fig. 1a) showed C=C stretching vibrations in aromatic carbons and C=O stretching vibrations in -COOH at about 1602 cm−1 and 1686 cm−1, confirming the presence of -COOH group. The doublets at approximately 2968 and 2941 cm−1 were assigned to C-H stretching. The peak at 1203 cm−1 belonged to the C-O bond. At 3400 cm−1, a signal was attributed to O-H stretching. A material containing functional groups such as phenolic hydroxyl and carboxylic groups was obtained from the hydrothermal process. In the Raman spectrum of CC-oxa, it was noted that the D, G, and D' bands dominated the spectrum (Fig. 1c). The D- and G- characteristics (at about 1335 and 1600 cm−1, respectively) were shared by all sp2-bonded carbons [63,64]. TGA analysis was used to assess the thermal stability of CC-oxa, and the findings were shown in Fig. 1b. The TGA diagram showed two separate weight losses. The first one was below 200 °C (about 5%), which was attributed to the elimination of organic solvent and water adsorbed on the surface. A significant weight loss was detected at 300–650 °C (about 95%), corresponding to the loss of organic functionality. When the temperature exceeded 650 °C, all the sample was burned out, which meant CC-oxa was utterly made of flammable materials. Therefore, CC-oxa could resist the reaction temperature up to 350 °C, which meant this catalyst was suitable for a microwave reactor. EDX elemental mapping validated the distribution of C and O elements in CC-oxa, as shown in Fig. 1e. The distribution of elements interpreted from random scanning of specified locations was determined using EDX mapping. As seen in Fig. 1f and g, carbon and oxygen make up the bulk of biomass-based compounds. Also, the C and O components in the CC-oxa structure were evenly distributed on the surface. The XRD patterns of CC-oxa (Fig. 1d) exhibited one strong, broad diffraction peak at 2θ angle of 20–30°, which is attributed to (002) planes of amorphous carbon. These patterns confirmed the material's disordered polycyclic aromatic carbon sheets [65]. The surface morphological characteristics of CC-oxa were examined by SEM (Fig. 1h and i). As observed, CC-oxa was a spherical shape with a micrometer diameter size of about 5–10 μm. Moreover, the particles were of different sizes. Natta et al. [66] also obtained a spherical shape of a carbonaceous catalyst created by hydrothermal carbonization of glucose, citric acid, and hydroxyethylsulfonic acid. All these results suggested that the CC-oxa was successfully synthesized [66]. The FT-IR spectra, TGA diagram, and total functional acidities of the other nine CC-acids were also presented in sections S5 and S6. All these results confirmed that the other nine CC-acids were also successfully synthesized. Several studies were designed to investigate the dehydration of carbohydrates to 5-HMF under various conditions, including solvents, catalysts, catalytic concentrations, substrates, and reaction times and temperatures. These investigations aimed to (i) identify an appropriate substrate for synthesizing 5-HMF in an aqueous medium and (ii) optimize reaction conditions to maximize 5-HMF production. The influence of various reaction parameters on 5-HMF yield and catalyst efficacy is discussed further below. 3.2 Substrate scope Regardless of the experimental settings, this investigation's primary product of the fructose reaction was always 5-HMF, while LA, Fur, DFF, FA, and FDCA were the by-products. To evaluate the potential of ten carbonaceous acidic solids CC-acid as catalysts for the formation of 5-HMF from carbohydrates, the substrates were examined first. CC-oxa was chosen as the representative of ten catalysts, DMSO was chosen as the solvent, and microwave heating in a domestic microwave oven was used as a heating method. The results were represented in Fig. 2 . As can be seen, after 10 min heating in a microwave reactor, only sucrose and fructose conversed into 5-HMF with high yields (41.3% and 88.5%, respectively) and low yield of by-products (about 2% of Fur). At the same time, other substrates gave meager yields of 5-HMF, proving they were effective in this transformation. The yields of 5-HMF from sucrose were lower than those produced from fructose. On the other hand, the direct synthesis of 5-HMF from sucrose offers a potential alternative method to 5-HMF production, which increases the substrate breadth of the catalyst and its sustainability. To form 5-HMF from disaccharides (maltose, lactose, and sucrose) or polysaccharides (starch and cellulose), the first step was the hydrolysis of glycosidic bond catalyzed by Brønsted acids, followed by the isomerization from glucose to fructose in the presence of Lewis acids and the dehydration of fructose to form 5-HMF. CC-oxa only contained Brønsted acid sites (-COOH and -OH), so the dehydration of fructose and hydrolysis/dehydration of sucrose to form 5-HMF could happen. On the other hand, maltose, lactose, starch, cellulose, or glucose could not convert to 5-HMF due to the lack of Lewis acid sites or base to catalyze the isomerization of glucose to fructose, resulting in the low yield of 5-HMF. Finally, mannitol and sorbitol could not form 5-HMF due to the difference in their structures to fructose. Therefore, fructose was shown to be a suitable substrate to form 5-HMF when carbonaceous acidic solids were employed as catalysts. Thus, it was used for further experiments. 3.3 Effect of solvents on the 5-HMF formation To understand the effect of solvents on this process, a wide range of solvents, including polar and non-polar ones, namely water, DMSO, sulfolane, 1,4-dioxane, EtOH, 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([EMIM]Cl), methylisobutylketone (MIBK), N,N-diformylformamide (DMF), tetrahydrofuran (THF), water: DMSO (1:1 v/v), nitrobenzene, acetonitrile (ACN), 1-butanol, and ethylene glycol under microwave irradiation were scrutinized for this conversion. The results were presented in Table 1 and Fig. 3 . It could be inferred from Table 1 that only DMSO and [EMIM]Cl yielded a high amount of 5-HMF under the reaction condition (88.5% and 56.9%, respectively). However, when [EMIM]Cl was used as a solvent (Fig. 3c), the 5-HMF yield was significantly reduced after 2 min of reaction, possibly due to the oligomerization of 5-HMF to produce humins. After 3 min under microwave irradiation, the reaction mixture color turned black and solidified. The high ability of DMSO to convert microwave energy to heat energy resulted in a shorter reaction time, the rate of glucose conversion to 5-HMF in DMSO solvent is higher than that in an aqueous medium [67]. In addition, DMSO prevented the reaction of 5-HMF from forming levulinic and formic acids because of the lack of water in the reaction system [68]. Therefore, DMSO was more efficient than [EMIM]Cl. When H2O was added into DMSO (1:1 v/v) to form a mixture of solvent (Fig. 3a), 5-HMF yield significantly dropped to 0.16% (10 min) and 0.72% (20 min) compared to 100% DMSO as solvent (5-HMF yield was 88.5%). It could be explained that the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF was not favorable in water because the equilibrium would shift to the left. In sulfolane (Fig. 3b), 5-HMF yield increased as time was prolonged and reached 15.1% after 20 min microwave heating. FDCA was the second product detected; its yield reached 20.5% after 20 min. When 1,4-dioxane was employed as a solvent, 5-HMF was not detected, but there were LA and FA with yields of 54.6% and 6.4%, respectively. It could be seen in Table 1 that EtOH, DMF, MIBK, ACN, 1-butanol, ethylene glycol, nitrobenzene, and THF were not suitable to be solvents for the conversion of fructose to 5-HMF due to the low boiling points of EtOH, ACN, and THF and low polarities of THF, 1-butanol and MIBK, which were not suitable to conduct heat from a microwave and solute fructose. For the cases of nitrobenzene and ethylene glycol, due to their viscosity which prevented them from conducting heat completely for the whole system, they were still not suitable solvents for this process. In conclusion, DMSO was used as reaction media for further experiments. 3.4 Effect of heating method on 5-HMF formation In general, in all reaction conditions, yields of 5-HMF increased as time was prolonged. When an ultrasonic bath was used (Fig. 4 a), the highest 5-HMF yield was 10.3% after 5 h, and it was the lowest 5-HMF yield in the longest reaction time among all cases. The temperature of the ultrasonic bath was from 60 – 64 °C, and that range of temperature was too low for the dehydration of fructose. In addition, microwave heating yielded the highest 5-HMF amount (91.4%) in a shorter time (20 min) (Fig. 4b). Moreover, after only 10 min, the 5-HMF yield when using microwave heating almost was high (88.5%), which could be applied to shorten the reaction time. Additionally, by-product yields were low (almost 0 except for furfural whose yield was lower than 3% after 10 min). The reason why using microwave heating helped shorten reaction time was because of the high ability of DMSO to convert microwave energy to heat energy [67]. In general, it has been claimed that this unique microwave effect is the consequence of directly interacting the electric field with molecules in the reaction media. Some researchers have claimed that microwave heating enhances the efficient collisions of reactant particles, increasing the pre-exponential component in the Arrhenius equation [69]. It also suggests that MW effects on solid surfaces might provide energy and mechanistic benefits to catalytic reactions [70,71]. The microwave effect is thought to be caused by selective heating of MW-absorbing molecules, such as the catalyst's carboxylic and hydroxyl groups, DMSO, and fructose. Under MW irradiation, reactants containing polar groups increase their rotation and shift from the ground state to the transition state, which increases reactivity by decreasing activation energy [72]. The thermal impact of the MW is defined as dielectric heating caused by polar molecules, such as the -COOH and -OH of the catalyst and the -OH groups of fructose [73,74]. At each alternation of the electric field, those groups shift their orientation, causing friction and locally causing a different c.q. and greater temperature, resulting in an enhanced reaction rate. Secondary thermal processes such as conduction and convection are unavoidable, further homogenizing temperature [73]. Stiegman and colleagues discovered a strong MW-specific influence on the examined reactions, since the MW not only selectively heated the substrate, but also changed the reaction's major thermokinetic stages [75]. In addition, the conversion of fructose to 5-HMF was also conducted in higher MW powers, namely, medium-low level (264 W) and medium level (440 W), and the results were depicted in Fig. 4c. It can be seen that at higher MW power, the 5-HMF yields were always higher than that of the lowest level (80 W, Fig. 4b) at all the reaction time. Moreover, 5-HMF yields of medium-low energy level were also lower than those of medium energy level. In conclusion, MW power had a positive effect on the formation of 5-HMF from fructose. The highest 5-HMF yield (78.8%) was achieved at only 5 min (half shorter than that of the lowest energy level) when the MW power of 440 W was applied. Therefore, higher energy levels helped shorten the reaction time. However, the aim of this study is not only to save time but also to save energy. Thus, the lowest MW energy level was chosen for further experiments. For conventional heating at different temperatures (Fig. 5 a-d), the 5-HMF yields increased over time. When the reaction temperature was 80 °C, the 5-HMF yield was 14.5% after 3 h, and when the temperature increased to 100 °C, the 5-HMF yield raised to 20.6%. At 120 °C and 140 °C, 5-HMF yields were higher, 26.8% and 34.8%, respectively. In conclusion, as temperature increased, 5-HMF yields after 3 h increased. It was because fructose dehydration reaction to 5-HMF was an endothermic process [76]. The highest 5-HMF yield at 80 °C was 14.5% after 3 h, while that was 20.6% after 3 h at 100 °C. For 120 °C and 140 °C, the highest 5-HMF yields were achieved after 120 min (31.0%) and 45 min (41.1%), respectively. For side products, LA and Fur were not detected at all the examined points, while DFF and FDCA yields were low, less than 1.5% and 0.02%, respectively (Fig. 5 and Table S8.4). The 5-HMF yields reached the plateau and dropped at 120 °C and 140 °C after 2 h and 1 h, respectively. It was possibly due to the oligomerization of 5-HMF to produce humins which could not be detected through NMR or HPLC or the formation of other by-products [77]. The temperature of the reaction in the MW oven was measured and it was about 130 °C. Therefore, a comparison experiment was conducted with the same condition as the one in the MW oven: fructose (1 mmol), CC-oxa (5 mg), DMSO (3 mL), 130 °C without stirring. The result was demonstrated in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that the two highest 5-HMF yields, 74.3% and 77.3% were achieved after 90 and 180 min of reaction time. These values are compared to the highest 5-HMF yield (79.9%) when applying the MW condition. However, the reaction time for conventional heating to achieve the highest 5-HMF yield (90 min) was much higher than that of MW heating (10 min) (9 times higher). Therefore, MW heating can help to shorten the reaction time, save energy, and increase 5-HMF yield. A comparison of the results showed that 5-HMF formation from the conventional heating (45% at 140 °C after 45 min) was lower than that of the microwave-assisted reaction (91% after 20 min) with the same CC-oxa loading. Thus, MW increased furanic chemical yields while decreasing reaction time, which may be attributed chiefly to "microwave effects." The dipole rotations of polar units or groups (here were -COOH and -OH groups) are frequently associated with the energy absorption of substances. The regular alignment of polar groups with an alternate electromagnetic field causes polar group vibration and friction with surrounding molecules. Because of the regular friction, a substantial quantity of local heat is generated around those polar groups [27,78]. Ji et al. [78] also verified the role of -SO4 2− groups on the surface materials containing sulfate groups or being dedoped sulfate groups in generating heat under MW irradiation. It was shown that there were important solution temperature decreases when catalysts were de-doped, which confirmed the key role of -SO4 2− groups to polarize the surface and generate heat. These arise because microwave radiation is directly coupled with possible solvent, chemical, or catalyst particles in the reaction mixture, causing effective inner heating or in-core volumetric impact heating. As a result, it avoids the problems of traditional heating, such as partial overheating [79]. Furthermore, a directional impact of polar molecules in an electromagnetic field may be used to reduce the activation energy or enhance the pre-exponential coefficient in the Arrhenius equation, resulting in a more efficient and transparent chemical process. Therefore, microwave heating was chosen as the optimal heating for further investigation [72]. 3.5 Comparison of the catalytic activities of ten catalysts and other acidic catalysts The catalytic activities of ten carbonaceous acidic catalysts CC-acids for the conversion of fructose to 5-HMF were presented in Figure S2. In general, as time prolonged, the yield of 5-HMF increased gradually until 10 min. After 10 min, the 5-HMF yields in almost cases remained unchanged or increased a little bit so that the further reactions would be limited in reaction time to 10 min. This rise in 5-HMF yield with increasing reaction time was consistent with the pattern for dehydration of fructose in water and water-DMSO solvents employing mineral acids and an ion-exchange resin catalyst under MW irradiation [80,81]. Moreover, all ten catalysts gave 5-HMF yields after 20 min above 80% because of their high acid contents. For by-products, the amounts of by-produced DFF, Fur, and FDCA were indicated to be lower than 0.5%, 3.1%, and 3.5%, respectively, while LA (except for CC-pTSA and CC-lac) and FA were not detected in all the experiments (Fig. S2 and Table S8.5). It is worth noting that CC-acid with high acidity on the surface increased the acidity of the whole reaction mixture leading to the formation of unwanted tar/humin or by-products, resulting in the decrease of 5-HMF yield [82]. The effect of the prepared catalysts was measured in terms of yield of 5-HMF, TON, TOF, E-factor, PMI, and STY. A comparison of the catalytic performance of ten CC-acid catalysts was summarized in Tables 2 and 3 . TON and TOF of ten catalysts at 1 and 3 min versus their acidities and 5-HMF yields were depicted in Table 2. After 1 min, 5-HMF yields of ten catalysts were almost 0% (except for CC-lac, CC-ben, and CC-oxa with 5-HMF yields of 0.13%, 0.73%, and 1.41%, respectively). As could be seen, CC-oxa gave the highest TON and TOF after 1 min among ten materials. In the cases of 3 min, CC-lac and CC-HCl obtained the highest TOF numbers (387.4 and 373.4 h−1, respectively). The E-factor and PMI values were calculated for the ten CC-acid catalysts shown in Table 3. All the catalysts had E-factor values below 1, which fitted the Roger Sheldon E-factor criterion for green synthesis of bulk chemicals. CC-oxa gave the lowest value of E-factor (0.130) with a PMI of 1.13. Upon further higher acidities of some catalysts, there was a slight decrease in their 5-HMF yields. Of the ten variants, CC-ole, CC-oxa, and CC-HCl showed the most optimal catalytic activities for 5-HMF formation. However, according to the TGA curve of CC-ole (Figure S5.2c), it should be noted that excess oleic acid might not be eliminated on CC-ole's surface. To determine the efficiency of carbonaceous catalysts in the dehydration of fructose, some commercial mineral acids (H2SO4 solution (98%), HCl solution (37%), and H3PO4 solution (85%)), strong organic acid (pTSA), and other solid acids (bentonite, activated silica gel) were used as catalysts for this process under microwave irradiation. The results were presented in Table 4 . It could be seen that carbonaceous catalysts had comparative catalytic activities (88.5% for CC-oxa) to the mineral acids (60–69%) as well as other solid acids (56.2% for activated silica gel). In addition, solid acids had many advantages such as facile post-reaction separation, reusability of catalysts, and high stability when compared to homogeneous ones. 3.6 The comparison of CC-oxa and CC-HCl for the conversion of glucose and sucrose to 5-HMF To compare the catalytic activities of CC-oxa and CC-HCl, they were employed to catalyze glucose and sucrose into 5-HMF under the same conditions. The results were demonstrated in Fig. 7 a and b. As seen in Fig. 7a, 5-HMF yields from the glucose of two catalysts were much low after 20 min (0.51% for CC-oxa and 0.90% for CC-HCl). Because of the lack of Lewis acid sites to catalyze the isomerization of glucose to fructose, 5-HMF could not be formed. Fig. 7b indicated that 5-HMF yields of CC-HCl and CC-oxa were approximately similar for 20 min. However, at the time of 15 min, the 5-HMF yield of CC-oxa was much higher than that of CC-HCl (50.6% and 42.1%, respectively). In addition, HCl could cause many environmental problems and could be corrosive to the equipment. The performance of CC-oxa and CC-HCl on converting sucrose to 5-HMF was measured in terms of yield of 5-HMF, TON, TOF, E-factor, and PMI. The results were summarized in Table 5 . As could be seen, E-factor numbers of the two catalysts were lower than 1 at the time longer than 5 min. It was noted that TON and TOF of the conversion of sucrose to 5-HMF using CC-oxa and CC-HCl as catalysts were tantamount at longer times. However, at 1 and 3 min, TON and TOF numbers of CC-oxa for the conversion of sucrose to 5-HMF were higher than those of CC-HCl. In addition, due to the environmental problem of HCl in the catalyst synthesis step, CC-oxa was more favorable. The effect of CC-HCl and CC-oxa on the yields of 5-HMF from fructose dehydration was also examined by conducting two experiments with the same conditions such as fructose (1 mmol), DMSO (3 mL), conventional heating at 130 °C without stirring (to simulate the condition in the MW oven), and the same amount of CC-oxa or CC-HCl (5 mg). The results were indicated in Fig. 8 . As can be seen, 5-HMF yields under the catalysis of CC-oxa were always higher than those from CC-HCl at all the screened reaction times. The highest 5-HMF yields of CC-oxa and CC-HCl were 77.3% and 58.6%, respectively after 180 min. Therefore, CC-oxa was used for later experiments. 3.7 Effect of catalytic loading on 5-HMF yield To optimize the reaction conditions, the dehydration of fructose into 5-HMF was investigated with various catalyst loadings. The effect of catalyst loading concerning 5-HMF yield was demonstrated in Fig. 9 a–d. The amount of CC-oxa varied from 1, 3, 5, to 10 mg while other reaction parameters were constant at 1 mmol of fructose for 10 min, and DMSO (3 mL) as a solvent. It was found that the 5-HMF yield was affected by the dosage of CC-oxa. In general, in four cases, the 5-HMF yield increased versus time. As demonstrated in Fig. 9, increasing the CC-oxa loadings from 1.0 mg to 10.0 mg raised the 5-HMF yield from 5.8% to 65.9% after 3 min. The studies with a high catalyst loading boosted 5-HMF production, indicating that the kinetic of fructose dehydration is quick in the presence of a higher catalytic loading. Under identical reaction conditions of 3 mg CC-oxa and after 5 min in DMSO, the highest yield of 5-HMF (79.9%) was obtained while in the case of 1 mg CC-oxa, the highest 5-HMF yield was achieved (67.1%) after 10 min. For 5 and 10 min, the highest 5-HMF yields were obtained after 7 min (60.7%) and 10 min (71,2%), respectively. 5-HMF yields tended to decrease at 3, 5, and 10 mg (Fig. 9b–d), which was owing to an overabundance of acidic sites, which not only results in the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF but also in the oligomerization of 5-HMF to produce humins [77]. In all experiments, the amounts of by-produced DFF and FDCA were indicated to be lower than 0.04% and 0.05%, respectively, while Fur and LA were not detected (Fig. 9 and Table S8.7) The fructose conversion and 5-HMF selectivity were presented in Table 6 . It was concluded that fructose conversion and 5-HMF selectivity were affected by time and fructose conversion at all times was higher than 70.0%. The 5-HMF selectivity was high (from 60.0 to 79.7%), except for 1 min because of the short reaction time. After 10 min of reaction time, the highest fructose conversion was 84.2%, while the maximum 5-HMF selectivity was achieved at a 7-min reaction time (79.7%). 3.8 The scale-up reaction of fructose conversion to 5-HMF in DMSO with the presence of CC-oxa The scale-up ability of the 5 mmol of fructose conversion to 5-HMF in DMSO (25 mL) with the presence of CC-oxa (15 mg) was examined, and the results were shown in Fig. 10 . After the first 5 min, the 5-HMF yield was quite low (<2%) and it increased significantly from the seventh minute of reacting. After 10 min, the 5-HMF yield was only 31.7%, much lower than the reaction's, with the molar fructose being 1 mmol (88.5%). It could be attributed to a large amount of solvent and the condition without stirring in the domestic microwave oven, which made it hard for fructose molecules to come into contact with the catalyst's active sites, resulting in a significant decrease in the 5-HMF yield. For other by-products (DFF, Fur, FDCA, and LA), their yields were almost 0 in all the examined reaction times. 3.9 Examination of the recovery ability of CC-oxa The FT-IR spectra of CC-oxa and recycled CC-oxa (CC-oxa-2) were indicated in Figure S5.3a. As could be seen from the results, all the functional groups of the initial catalysts were still retained well in the recovered ones. EDX results (Fig. S5.3b) showed that the elemental compositions of the recovered catalyst consisted of C and O elements. The elemental mapping validated the distribution of C and O elements in recovered CC-oxa, as shown in Fig. S5.3e-f. In the recovered CC-oxa, carbon and oxygen elements still make up the majority of glucose-based materials. They were also evenly distributed on the surface. The surface morphology of recovered CC-oxa was examined by SEM (Fig. S5.3 c-d). As observed, CC-oxa still kept the spherical shape with a micrometer diameter size of about 5–10 μm, which proved that after being used, the elemental composition and morphology of CC-oxa were also constant. The recovery ability of CC-oxa was examined and shown in Fig. 11 . The 5-HMF yield fell drastically from 31.7% to 15.8% over the first recycle run. After the first cycle, we noticed a shift in the color of the reaction solution from white to orange-brown, which was also observed by De's group when converting fructose to 5-HMF using AlCl3 as a catalyst in water under MW [83]. As proven, the likely explanation for this was the production and later accumulation of humins on the catalyst exterior, which deactivated the active sites after the first run, resulting in a decline in 5-HMF yield. We expected that humins accumulated on the surface of the CC-oxa-2 catalyst would disrupt the dehydration phase catalyzed by Brønsted acid from -COOH and -OH groups. Furthermore, in Fig. S5.3a, the peak at 1700 cm−1 of the recovered catalyst is sharper and deeper than that of the original catalyst. This demonstrated an increase in compounds containing the C=O group on the catalyst surface upon recovery, presumably due to humin adhesion. Consequently, the catalyst's efficiency after recovery has been drastically diminished [56,84]. According to reports, 5-HMF has a higher affinity for the Brønsted acid site [85]. Following that, the adsorbed 5-HMF condenses to form humins, corresponding to the reaction color change. The heavily bound 5-HMF on the CC-oxa-2 exterior may additionally obstruct active sites and catalytic pores, preventing subsequent rehydration reactions to organic acids. To examine the effect of acid sites leaching to the solution, an experiment was conducted by microwaving a solution mixture of fructose (1 mmol), CC-oxa (5 mg), and DMSO (3 mL) at 1, 3, and 5 min. After 5 min, the reaction was stopped, CC-oxa was centrifuged and filtered out of the reaction mixture. Then, the mixture without CC-oxa was continuously microwaved in the oven after 1, 3, and 5 min (6, 8, and 10 min in total, respectively). The 5-HMF yield versus reaction time was depicted in Fig. 12 . As can be seen when time increased from 1 to 5 min, 5-HMF yield also increased rapidly from almost 0% to 70%. However, after discarding CC-oxa, 5-HMF yield decreased gradually over time (63.2%, 61.5%, and 49.4% after 6, 8, and 10 min, respectively). Compared to the case in which CC-oxa was at the same amount (5 mg) and not discarded (Fig. 4b), it could be seen that in Fig. 4b, 5-HMF yield continued to increase after 5 min and up to 10 min while in Fig. 12 decreased after 5 min. The drop in 5-HMF yield could be attributed to the formation of humins via the cross-polymerization of 5-HMF [82]. It could also be concluded that the acid sites on CC-oxa surface did not leach into the solution because if this happened, 5-HMF yield after CC-oxa discarding must have increased to time. Therefore, the accumulation of humins on the catalyst exterior may be the major reason why CC-oxa was deactivated after the first run. 3.10 Comparative analysis of the CC-oxa catalyst with previous literature reports Table 7 shows the comparative dehydration results of fructose to 5-HMF catalyzed by various carbonaceous catalysts by microwave and conventional heating methods in DMSO, water, and ionic liquids. Qi et al. pointed out that when carbonaceous microspheres materials formed by the hydrothermal carbonization of glucose were employed as catalysts in 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([BMIM][Cl]) at 100 °C for 90 min (Table 7, entry 1). However, this process required a long reaction time, expensive ion liquid, and long hydrothermal time. By employing the same hydrothermal protocol to synthesize carbonaceous catalysts but with more ingredients, including glucose, HCl, Poly(4-styrenesulfonic acid-co-maleic acid) sodium salt (PSSMA), pTSA, and/or acrylic acid (AA), Lyu and co-workers reported a 5-HMF yield of 90.6% after 5 min of reaction time in DMSO by spherical carbon superstructures (SCG) as a catalyst (Table 7, entry 2). However, the weight ratio of catalyst to fructose was higher (40%) than that in this study (2.8%) (Table 7, entry 7). Moreover, the ingredients to synthesize SCG were too much. Gou et al. evaluated the effect of a lignin-derived sulfonated solid acid catalyst (LCC) on 5-HMF yield via a microwave-assisted conversion of fructose (Table 7, entry 3). It was found that under the MW power of 100 W, a 5-HMF yield of 84% was achieved after 10 min in the presence of DMSO-[BMIM][Cl] (6:4 wt/wt) as solvent. However, LCC synthesized by a three-step protocol for a long time, a high amount of catalyst used and expensive solvent were disadvantages of this report. The same disadvantages were assigned to Mu's study (Table 7, Entry 5) and the cost of materials was also high. A microwave-assisted carbonization of glucose at 180 °C for 2 h was reported by Songo and co-workers (Table 7, entry 4). The obtained solid (C_S) was employed as a catalyst for fructose dehydration irradiated by microwave in DMSO for 15 min. A moderate 5-HMF yield of 25% was obtained, which was lower than that when CC-oxa played the role of a catalyst and yielded 79.7% of 5-HMF after 10 min (Table 7, entry 7) even when the amount of C-S was much higher. Kong and co-workers also reported the application of a glucose-based carbon material for the formation of 5-HMF and the highest yield of 88.3% was achieved (Table 7, Entry 6). However, the carbonization time was longer and the reaction temperature was much higher than in this study while the 5-HMF yields were comparative. All of these reports indicated that microwave irradiation and carbonaceous catalysts were efficient for the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF in DMSO within a short reaction time. 3.11 Product characterization The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of isolated 5-HMF from the liquid-liquid extraction with ethyl acetate followed by flash column chromatography with a solvent eluent of hexane/ethyl acetate=3/2 were given in the supporting information (S7). 3.12 Proposed mechanism for the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF by CC-oxa Following the results of the experiments, a plausible reaction pathway for synthesizing 5-HMF from a monosaccharide using CC-oxa as a catalyst has been proposed (Scheme 2 ). Initially, fructose was readily absorbed on the surface of the CC-oxa catalyst via hydrogen-bonding interactions between the numerous carboxyl and hydroxyl groups of CC-oxa and hydroxyl groups of fructose. The triple dehydrations of fructose to 5-HMF are mainly due to Brønsted acid [87]. In this study, the carboxylic groups on the surface are responsible for this water removal by the E1 mechanism of 1,2-elimination. Similarly, hydrogen bonding with CC-oxa catalyst is thought to stimulate the O-H bonds of fructose, which improves the dehydration step. After the first dehydration step, an intermediate enol was formed. Then, it is converted into aldehyde through keto-enol tautomerism. Finally, two water molecules are released to form 5-HMF. 4 Conclusions This work investigated the preparation and catalytic activities of various amorphous carbons bearing Brønsted acid sites as efficient heterogeneous catalysts for converting fructose to 5-HMF irradiated using a commercial microwave oven. The Brønsted acid sites played the catalytic role in dehydrating fructose to 5-HMF. We have denoted that CC-acids are great catalysts for rapidly converting fructose into 5-HMF in DMSO under commercial microwave irradiation. The results revealed the highest yields of 5-HMF using CC-oxa as the catalyst among ten CC-acids. The formations of 5-HMF from fructose from a wide range of substrates and in various heating techniques, as well as solvents, were investigated, suggesting that fructose, domestic microwave irradiation, and DMSO are the most suitable substrate, heating source, MW power, and solvent for this procedure, respectively. Then, a detailed study was carried out to optimize the reaction and maximize 5-HMF yield by modifying different parameters, namely reaction time and catalyst amount. The highest yield for 5-HMF was 79.9 % after 20 min under household microwave irradiation using fructose as the substrate, DMSO as the solvent, and CC-oxa as the catalyst. With a small catalyst amount of 3 mg, the best 5-HMF yield was achieved, demonstrating this study's resource-saving and high applicability. The reusability of CC-oxa was also examined, and the results showed that the primary function groups on the catalyst's surface remained unchanged after the first run and wash. However, there was a significant loss in 5-HMF yield when using the recovered catalyst, which might be attributed to the adsorption of humins on the active sites. The remarkable advantages of this process are without requiring potentially toxic metal salt, easy operation, short reaction time, low catalyst loading, and high 5-HMF yield and selectivity with low by-product formation. DMSO as a solvent instead of costly ionic liquids makes this procedure an ecologically friendly and economically appealing option. A mechanism for the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF was also proposed. This paves the way for new sorts of design amorphous carbon bearing both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites for the conversion of glucose into 5-HMF. coredata.dc:description: Recently, the catalytic conversion of fructose to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) has attracted much interest. The idea of a low-cost, sustainable, energy-efficient method is critical to obtain excellent yield and selectivity for the target product 5-HMF. In this work, microwave (MW) irradiation was chosen as a heating source for the conversion of fructose to 5-HMF with the presence of various amorphous carbons containing Brønsted acid sites as catalysts in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as a solvent. The catalysts’ morphology, surface functional groups, thermal stability, and compositions of the obtained solids were examined by scanning electron microscope (SEM), elemental mapping, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), energy dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (EDX), Raman spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques. The effect of solvent, heating technique, MW power, time, and catalytic loading on the reaction was studied thoroughly. The highest 5-HMF yield of 79.9% and 5-HMF selectivity of 79.7% were achieved with the optimal condition. 5-HMF was easily separated using a liquid-liquid extraction procedure with high purity. Moreover, the catalyst can be quickly recovered and reused. MW irradiation has proved to selectively and efficiently promote the formation of 5-HMF with high yield in a short reaction time. A mechanism for the formation 5-HMF from fructose was also proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Microwave-assisted conversion of fructose to 5-HMF using carbonaceous acidic catalysts
